snippet.textDisplay: I'm curious then, what are the drawbacks of moving the computation of dithering itself on the video player? Does that end up being potentially CPU/GPU intensive in some cases, and that the prevalence of youtube on many different device-performance-levels implies that this would be more difficult to implement? Would this then potentially be solved with a toggle in youtube as another video-quality toggle, much like how we can manually adjust the resolution? Or would it just be too much effort for a relatively low audience/use-case?
snippet.textOriginal: I'm curious then, what are the drawbacks of moving the computation of dithering itself on the video player? Does that end up being potentially CPU/GPU intensive in some cases, and that the prevalence of youtube on many different device-performance-levels implies that this would be more difficult to implement? Would this then potentially be solved with a toggle in youtube as another video-quality toggle, much like how we can manually adjust the resolution? Or would it just be too much effort for a relatively low audience/use-case?

snippet.textDisplay: Here's a youtube compression lifehack everyone should know: You can render your 1080p video in 4K and upload it to youtube. Youtube allocates more bandwidth for 4K videos so your 1080p video will look much better upscaled at 4K due to more available bandwidth.
snippet.textOriginal: Here's a youtube compression lifehack everyone should know: You can render your 1080p video in 4K and upload it to youtube. Youtube allocates more bandwidth for 4K videos so your 1080p video will look much better upscaled at 4K due to more available bandwidth.

snippet.textDisplay:
In terms of mobile phones, I remember the old flagship Samsung phones (circa 2013) were great for just skipping most of the darker shades of green and hoping nobody noticed. And to be fair, not many people did notice, until they pulled out some digital colour charts as part of a review.. I'm sure other manufacturers were just as guilty of these behaviours, I just remember Samsung were particularly guilty of it, while still trying to boast about the "superior" quality of their products. This was done for the darker shades primarily because they're less easily noticed, the same reason some speaker manufacturers will make their subwoofers louder rather than higher quality. Many people will get volume confused with depth, and be satisfied with the Snoop Dogg sounds now present in their living rooms.

It's not always about the quality of the source material. Unless we are still using a CRT display with an RGB input, I wouldn't expect perfect colour results anyway.
snippet.textOriginal:
In terms of mobile phones, I remember the old flagship Samsung phones (circa 2013) were great for just skipping most of the darker shades of green and hoping nobody noticed. And to be fair, not many people did notice, until they pulled out some digital colour charts as part of a review.. I'm sure other manufacturers were just as guilty of these behaviours, I just remember Samsung were particularly guilty of it, while still trying to boast about the "superior" quality of their products. This was done for the darker shades primarily because they're less easily noticed, the same reason some speaker manufacturers will make their subwoofers louder rather than higher quality. Many people will get volume confused with depth, and be satisfied with the Snoop Dogg sounds now present in their living rooms.

It's not always about the quality of the source material. Unless we are still using a CRT display with an RGB input, I wouldn't expect perfect colour results anyway.

snippet.textDisplay: Eugh, either through ignorance or a misguided desire for simplicity, you completely glossed over the fact that the pixel values in RGB are not translated linearly by the monitor into a real light level. A pixel value of 200 outputs much more than twice the amount of light than a pixel value of 100. sRGB curves. This was done in an attempt to mitigate the very effect you're describing, yet you didn't even mention it nor explained why it doesn't go far enough.
snippet.textOriginal: Eugh, either through ignorance or a misguided desire for simplicity, you completely glossed over the fact that the pixel values in RGB are not translated linearly by the monitor into a real light level. A pixel value of 200 outputs much more than twice the amount of light than a pixel value of 100. sRGB curves. This was done in an attempt to mitigate the very effect you're describing, yet you didn't even mention it nor explained why it doesn't go far enough.

snippet.textDisplay:
Alright im gonna guess before watching:
The human eye does not perceive brightness in a linear way. And because of that, a dark background or video in general with slight changes in darkness on it in reality represent a WAY more subtle difference in actual number of photons than a bright background with subtle changes in brightness.
Because of this, digital devices have more trouble making it a smooth color transition because there are way fewer different 'levels of brightness' left to work with if the video is already dark.

EDIT: alright alright, i wasnt completely off even though it was far from complete...
snippet.textOriginal:
Alright im gonna guess before watching:
The human eye does not perceive brightness in a linear way. And because of that, a dark background or video in general with slight changes in darkness on it in reality represent a WAY more subtle difference in actual number of photons than a bright background with subtle changes in brightness.
Because of this, digital devices have more trouble making it a smooth color transition because there are way fewer different 'levels of brightness' left to work with if the video is already dark.

EDIT: alright alright, i wasnt completely off even though it was far from complete...

snippet.textDisplay: Do clever compression algorithms detect and recreate dithering? Because I get that transmitting exactly the value of each pixel is expensive but couldn't they smear a gradient on there instead of color lines and then when decompressing client-side add dithering. Basically, take the areas you would normally reduce to one color (color stripes) and then replace them with a SVG style gradient object which is very data light. You could even save the color as 32 or even 64 bits as this is for a larger area and thus doesn't happen to often. Then later just render this on the screen using dithering. I guess the question boils down to: If the exact arrangement of pixels doesn't matter why does drawing randomly dithered borders take more bandwidth then clean ones.
snippet.textOriginal: Do clever compression algorithms detect and recreate dithering? Because I get that transmitting exactly the value of each pixel is expensive but couldn't they smear a gradient on there instead of color lines and then when decompressing client-side add dithering. Basically, take the areas you would normally reduce to one color (color stripes) and then replace them with a SVG style gradient object which is very data light. You could even save the color as 32 or even 64 bits as this is for a larger area and thus doesn't happen to often. Then later just render this on the screen using dithering. I guess the question boils down to: If the exact arrangement of pixels doesn't matter why does drawing randomly dithered borders take more bandwidth then clean ones.

snippet.textDisplay: This is why older digital cameras with CCD sensors and large glass lenses take better pictures, especially when set on highest quality. They don't use massive lossy compression of dark areas. I've taken some old digital photos with a brightly lit subject and an apparently all black background, then in Photoshop done some level adjustment and BAM there's all kinds of stuff that the camera picked up that was hidden in the dark.
snippet.textOriginal: This is why older digital cameras with CCD sensors and large glass lenses take better pictures, especially when set on highest quality. They don't use massive lossy compression of dark areas. I've taken some old digital photos with a brightly lit subject and an apparently all black background, then in Photoshop done some level adjustment and *BAM* there's all kinds of stuff that the camera picked up that was hidden in the dark.

snippet.textDisplay:
To say nothing of OLED panels and the headaches they bring. The black depth on LED is poor, which helps smoosh the lowest 8 or so black colours together; on an OLED screen, and the difference between those lowest blacks is really visible. Combine this with the fact that for a lot of older sources, the production line were editing and mastering it on LED screens, and suddenly there's loads of noise, artifacts and mistakes in the dark areas that the original editing staff couldn't even see.
Nobody tells you this stuff when you buy an OLED TV.
snippet.textOriginal:
To say nothing of OLED panels and the headaches they bring. The black depth on LED is poor, which helps smoosh the lowest 8 or so black colours together; on an OLED screen, and the difference between those lowest blacks is really visible. Combine this with the fact that for a lot of older sources, the production line were editing and mastering it on LED screens, and suddenly there's loads of noise, artifacts and mistakes in the dark areas that the original editing staff couldn't even see.
Nobody tells you this stuff when you buy an OLED TV.

snippet.textDisplay: Its why the 'bitrate tunnels' in GTA5 look so awful as they use masses of bandwidth due to the volume of changing pixels! Its crazy that if Rock star had decided on either a solid colour or psudo translucent plastic effect the videos would be perfectly fine, but because they went for a mesh and its moving at speed (in races) it looks utterly awful! Design challenges for the modern world eh?
snippet.textOriginal: Its why the 'bitrate tunnels' in GTA5 look so awful as they use masses of bandwidth due to the volume of changing pixels! Its crazy that if Rock star had decided on either a solid colour or psudo translucent plastic effect the videos would be perfectly fine, but because they went for a mesh and its moving at speed (in races) it looks utterly awful! Design challenges for the modern world eh?
